You should know that I thus, with great diligence and great skillful means, taught and transformed sentient beings, gathering this anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.
Therefore, good men,

You should give rise to such desire, diligence, and heedfulness, cultivating and gathering anuttara-samyak-sambodhi, just as when I practiced the bodhisattva path, you should also benefit and teach and transform sentient beings as I do.
Good men,
In this Worthy Eon, the Buddhas who appear in the world, none do not praise me, saying such things:

'The Buddha Shakyamuni deeply practiced diligence like this, the Buddha Shakyamuni was endowed with diligence like this, the Buddha Shakyamuni was fully endowed with the perfection of diligence like this.
When the Buddha Shakyamuni was practicing the bodhisattva path, he taught and transformed sentient beings like this, emerging from the five turbidities to benefit innumerable sentient beings.
' Good men!
For this kind of practice of the Way, one should diligently arouse desire, diligence, and non-negligence.
Good men!

Although I have now attained supreme perfect enlightenment, my diligence is still unceasing. Even when reaching nirvana, I will still arouse diligence and shatter my bones and body like mustard seeds, and disperse my limbs and joints.
Why is this?
It is out of compassion for sentient beings in the future.

When I was practicing the bodhisattva path in previous lives, the sentient beings I had transformed sometimes made mistakes and fell into difficult situations. Wishing to rescue them, I gave rise to a mind of great compassion and distributed my relics, even down to the size of a mustard seed, all with spiritual power.

After my nirvana, if there are sentient beings who should be liberated through relics, their minds will attain purity. Having attained purity, they will accomplish their wishes in various places in the earth.
Good men!

When I was practicing the path in previous lives, I accomplished such a compassionate mind among sentient beings, and my bodily relics were shattered and distributed everywhere. This was my original vow.
Because of such immeasurable merits and virtues and the mind of great compassion, I will universally cover sentient beings in the evil world to come.
Good men!

If bodhisattvas are able to give rise to desire, diligence, and non-negligence in this Dharma, they will definitely make this vow. In the latter age, they will uphold, recite, and extensively explain such sutras for others. I will use my spiritual powers to enable bodhisattvas to uphold, recite, and extensively explain them for others. I will also entrust this sutra to these bodhisattvas because they are able to uphold, recite, and extensively explain it.
Why is it so?
All good men!
Wherever this sutra is, one should know that the Buddha is there, not extinguished. Therefore, the Tathagata entrusts this sutra to the bodhisattvas.
All good men!

You should know that in my past lives, I used such causes and conditions to gather in sentient beings. In this life, I also gather in sentient beings, and in future lives, I will also gather in sentient beings. That is to say, I protect and think of such sutra teachings, so that they will be widely circulated in the latter five hundred years.
All good men!

Whether in this world or after my nirvÄá¹‡a, if in villages, cities, mountains, forests, or wildernesses, there are such sÅ«tras, if one is able to uphold, recite, and explain them to others, know that the Buddha is present there.
Why is this?
I say that the buddhas are the Dharma body. Seeing the Dharma is seeing the Buddha. The Buddha should not be seen in terms of physical form.
If a person has faith in the Dharma and listens to the Dharma, that person will have faith in the Buddha and listen to the Buddha's words.

If a person is able to practice in accordance with the teachings in this Dharma, that person will see the Buddha. That person is called a speaker of truth, a speaker of the Dharma, and a practitioner in accordance with the Dharma.
Good men!
My body is neither Dharma nor non-Dharma. This is called practicing in accordance with the Dharma. This is called the foremost Dharma offering, namely, not being attached to Dharma or non-Dharma.
Why is this?
If one is attached to Dharma, it is not called seeing the Buddha.
Good men!
Not clinging to any dharma is called seeing the Buddha.
If one has nothing to see in all dharmas, this is called seeing the Buddha.
Why is it so?
The TathÄgata cannot be spoken of in terms of dharma, cannot be spoken of in terms of non-dharma, and also cannot be seen in terms of dharma.
Why is it so?
All good men!
As it is said in the sÅ«tra:
You bhiká¹£us!
If you know my teaching is like a raft, even the dharma should be abandoned, let alone the non-dharma.
If one can abandon the dharma and non-dharma, this is called seeing the Buddha.
Why is it so?
The TathÄgata is called the one who abandons all dharmas, not greedy for or accepting the names of dharmas, not falling into the dharmas of names.
How much less would one fall into the names of non-dharmas?
All good men!
Abandoning all dharma names is called the TathÄgata. One who can see in this way is called seeing the TathÄgata.
Why is it so?
Because one abandons views of all dharmas, it is called seeing the TathÄgata, because all dharmas are unobtainable.
Because one truly knows and sees all dharmas, it is called seeing the TathÄgata.
Good men!

If all dharmas are unobtainable and one abandons all dharmas, then there is no more conceptual proliferation, no names of dharmas or non-dharmas, no practice, no demonstration - this is called seeing the TathÄgata.
If a person can see the Dharma in this way, it is called seeing the TathÄgata.
If one can see the TathÄgata in this way, it is called right view.
If one sees differently, it is called wrong view. If one has wrong view, it is called false seeing. This person is not called a true seer.
Good men!

A true seer cuts off all paths of language. He is neither true nor false, neither existent nor non-existent. He is apart from all dharmas and does not grasp at any dharmas. He does not attain any dharmas. One who sees in this way is called seeing the TathÄgata.
Why is it so?
All good men!
The TathÄgata does not see the nature of dharmas as seen, and sees that the nature of all dharmas is apart from [the self], this is called the TathÄgata.
If one is able to see in this way, it is called right view.
All good men!
You should see the TathÄgata in this way.
You should observe as I have explained in observing the TathÄgata.

Those who observe in this way should know that all dharmas are the TathÄgata, should attain the suchness of all dharmas, should attain the true aspect of all dharmas, should know that all dharmas are the dharmas of the TathÄgata, should know that all dharmas are the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata, should know that all dharmas are the sphere of activity of the inconceivable.
All good men!
Therefore, I say that all dharmas are the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata, and the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata is a sphere of no activity.
Why is it so?
The sphere of activity of all dharmas is where there is no dharma to be practiced. Therefore, it is said that the sphere of non-practice is the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata.
The sphere of activity of all dharmas is precisely the sphere of non-practice, and the sphere of non-practice is precisely the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata.
Why is it so?
Because the sphere of activity of all dharmas is non-existent, the sphere of non-practice is the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata.
All spheres of activity enter the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata, which is not a sphere of activity.
Because the TathÄgata has realized and attained this Dharma, it is called the sphere of non-practice, which is the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata.
Good men!

One who is able to know that the sphere of activity of all dharmas is non-existent can enter the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata, can contemplate the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata, can seek the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata, and can also not be attached to the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata.
Why is it so?
Because this person knows that the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata is non-existent, and the sphere of activity of the TathÄgata is apart from the sphere of activity.

That is to say, all dharmas are ungraspable, indivisible, and ungraspable, therefore this is called the non-practice place, which is the TathÄgata's practice place. This is called entering the practice place of wisdom, because it does not enter any dharmas.
Why is it so?
Because all dharmas are without a gate, therefore this is the gate to enter.
Good men!
All dharmas are without entering or exiting, all dharmas are formless.
Why is it so?
The TathÄgata has nothing to attain in the Dharma.
What Dharma is there to exit or enter, to see or explain?
Good men!

This is called entering the gate of all dharmas, because it does not enter any characteristics. All dharmas are without combination or dispersion, without bondage or liberation. This is the gate of all dharmas because it is without a gate. This gate is called the gate that cannot be exited or entered, the gate that cannot be returned to or explained, the gate of ultimate non-arising. Through this Dharma gate, there is nothing to know or see in the Dharma.
By this Dharma door, there is no realization or entry into the Dharma.
Why is it so?
All good men!
All dharmas are without a gate, because a gate cannot be obtained.
Space is the gate of all dharmas, because from the beginning its nature is pure.ğŸ”½Non-cessation is the gate of all dharmas, because cessation is non-existent.
Boundlessness is the gate of all dharmas, because boundaries cannot be obtained.
Immeasurability is the gate of all dharmas, because measure cannot be obtained.
Borderlessness is the gate of all dharmas, because all borders are non-existent.
All good men!
If there are good men and good women who can enter this Dharma door, they will enter all Dharma doors, know all Dharma doors, and expound all Dharma doors.
Chapter 5: The Five Skandhas, Part 1 of the Sutra on the Retention of the World At that time, the Buddha told Bodhisattva Holder of the World:
Holder of the World!

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas wish to attain the true characteristics of all dharmas, if they wish to skillfully discriminate all the chapters and phrases of the Dharma, if they wish to attain the power of mindfulness, if they wish to be fully endowed with uninterrupted mindfulness in their next life, up to attaining supreme perfect enlightenment, they should quickly enter such a Dharma door, and within this Dharma door they will attain the light of wisdom.
Why is this?
Because within this Dharma they will quickly attain complete fulfillment.
Moreover, Posadha!

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas diligently cultivate and gather such a Dharma door, and enter the door of skillful means of this Dharma, then they will be able to attain the skillful means of discriminating the aggregates, the skillful means of discriminating the elements, the skillful means of discriminating the sense bases, the skillful means of the conditioned arising of dharmas, the skillful means of the four establishments of mindfulness, the skillful means of the five faculties, the skillful means of the eightfold noble path, the skillful means of worldly and supramundane dharmas, and the skillful means of discriminating conditioned and unconditioned dharmas.
Posadha!
What is meant by bodhisattvas discriminating the five aggregates as skillful means?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas correctly contemplate the five appropriated aggregates, namely, the aggregate of ignorance is the five appropriated aggregates, the aggregate of suffering is the five appropriated aggregates, the aggregate of delusion is the five appropriated aggregates, the aggregate of sickness and boils, the aggregate of an arrow lodged in the body is the five appropriated aggregates.
Bodhisattvas discriminate, contemplate, and select the aggregate of form that is appropriated.
What is meant by discriminating, contemplating, and selecting the aggregate of form that is appropriated?

This aggregate of form that is appropriated arises from the four great elements, and is provisionally named the aggregate of form that is appropriated. This aggregate of form is without self-nature, but is provisionally named the aggregate of form due to the combination of the four great elements.
The aggregate of form is without a creator, without a cause of creation, without creation, without arising, and without emergence, and is named the aggregate of form.

But it is provisionally named the aggregate of form due to the four great elements that are grasped by previous karmic causes, and is not an aggregate that is form. It is like empty space, and the aggregate is actually without the characteristic of arising.
If one speaks of the aggregate of space, there is no dharma that arises in it, but only a name, therefore it is called the aggregate of space.

Ordinary people, in this non-aggregate aggregate, because of an inverted mind, without real reality, greedily attach to the five aggregates of self and the five aggregates of mine, my form aggregate and my form aggregate of mine, and so on, they greedily attach in this way.

These ordinary people, having greedily attached to form, in form rely on self and mine, have form, receive form, grasp form, cling to form, and rely on form, receiving various evil and unwholesome karma.
We should not follow the learning of ordinary people, we should diligently cultivate and accumulate the factors of enlightenment, and now we should correctly contemplate the aggregate of form.
When bodhisattvas correctly contemplate the aggregate of form, they know it is the same as a mass of foam.
How do they know it is the same as a mass of foam?
A mass of foam is without a mass.
It is only born from various conditions, cannot be grasped, and is not solid. In a mass of foam, there is no mass-like appearance. The absence of a mass is a mass of foam;
The form aggregate is also like this. In the form aggregate, there is no aggregate-like appearance.
When the bodhisattva contemplates in this way, he thinks like this:
'Ordinary beings are unable to correctly contemplate false form. They are unable to know form as impermanent as it truly is. They are unable to know the characteristics of form as they truly are.
We who have entered the right path should not be attached to falsehood, should not be attached to form.

Why is it so?ğŸ”½Form is a characteristic that cannot be attached to. Form only has a name but no definite characteristic. One should contemplate this form as having no definite characteristic, because it is apart from names, it is called form.

It is also said that the name 'form' is a characteristic of being harmed. The wise one penetrates and knows that this is without characteristics. We should skillfully know the expedient means of cultivating the signlessness of form, and not be attached to the characteristics of form.'
If a person is attached to the characteristics of form, they are attached to form. We should skillfully understand entering the characteristics of form.'
When the Bodhisattva observes in this way, he observes and selects form as it really is. This aggregate of form all arises from the conceptual discrimination of ordinary beings.
If a dharma arises from conceptual discrimination, then it does not arise. All conceptual discriminations are not real.

Ordinary beings rely on form that arises from inversion, are bound by form, and harmed by form. They go back and forth in suffering, and because of the darkness of ignorance, they greedily cling to form and do not let go. They see form as permanent and solid. This is how ordinary beings are bound by form.

Because they are bound by form, they go back and forth in hell, the realm of hungry ghosts, the animal realm, and the realms of gods and humans. They deeply crave the taste of form and do not see the faults and evils within form.
We should not follow the learning of ordinary beings. We should observe, select, discriminate, and cultivate the methods of form.

When discerning, contemplating, and selecting form, one sees the nature of form to be like a dream. It is like the forms in a dream, all arising from memory, imagination, conceptual thoughts, and the causes and conditions of what has been seen, heard, felt, and known. In a dream, one also knows oneself and others, and also sees earth, water, fire, and wind, and also sees mountains, rivers, and forests.
The forms in a dream are without certainty, but there is existence due to memory.
The characteristics of the aggregate of form are also like this, arising from the causes and conditions of karma from past lives, without any definite nature.
The bodhisattva thus contemplates and does not grasp form.

Whether it is the self or what belongs to the self, one simply correctly contemplates form as truly having the characteristic of impermanence, false and inverted. Sentient beings are inverted and attached, grasping form, whether it is one's own form or the form of others, whether it is one's own form or the form of others.
When correctly contemplating and selecting form in this way, one does not obtain form, does not see the nature of form, and is also not attached to the impermanence of form.

At that time, the bodhisattva, regarding form, completely eliminates all love and attachment, skillfully understands the correct characteristics of form, skillfully understands the equal characteristics of form, skillfully understands the characteristics of the cessation of form, skillfully understands the characteristics of the path to the cessation of form, skillfully understands that the aggregate of form comes from nowhere and goes nowhere, and thinks like this:
'This aggregate of form in the body arises from karmic retribution and contemplation, and is included in the four elements.
This aggregate of form in the body does not belong to self, does not belong to others, and has no owner. It does not arise from anywhere.'

Observing the aggregate of form like this, he does not greedily grasp or accept internal form, does not greedily grasp or accept external form, does not greedily grasp or accept past form, does not greedily grasp or accept future form, and does not greedily grasp or accept present form. He immediately understands that all aggregates of form are characterized by non-arising.
At that time, the bodhisattva neither extinguishes form nor seeks the Dharma of extinguishing form.
Dhá¹›ti!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas observe and select the aggregate of form grasped like this.
Dhá¹›á¸hataraÅ›rÄ«,
What is meant by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas observing and selecting the aggregates to be accepted?
Bodhisattvas contemplate like this:

'These feelings of suffering, pleasure, and neither suffering nor pleasure all arise from causes and conditions, belong to various causes and conditions, and enter into the characteristics of feeling.
In this, there is no one who feels, but it is only due to attachment that there is attachment, which is false and deluded, arising from conceptual discrimination.'
When bodhisattvas contemplate in this way, they think like this:
'These ordinary beings are bound by false feelings and harmed by the three kinds of feelings, namely feelings of suffering, pleasure, and neither suffering nor pleasure.
If ordinary beings experience pleasure, they are driven by the fetter of craving, and because they are driven by the fetter of craving, they are able to give rise to evil karma.
If they experience suffering, they are driven by the fetter of anger, and because they are driven by the fetter of anger, they give rise to various evil karmas.'

If one experiences neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, one is bound by the fetter of ignorance. Because one is bound by the fetter of ignorance, one does not escape from sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress.
We should not now follow the learning of ordinary people, but should contemplate phenomena correctly. We should contemplate feelings as they really are.'
The Bodhisattva contemplates the aggregate of feeling as it really is and thinks like this:

'The aggregate of feeling is not an aggregate. It arises from memory and conceptualization, and is associated with delusion. There is no one who feels. It only arises from the causes and conditions of past karma.
The intrinsic nature of all feelings is empty. There is no characteristic of feeling in feelings.'
The Bodhisattva contemplates and penetrates the aggregate of feeling, like raindrops and water bubbles, which arise and cease without certainty.

The aggregate of feeling is also like this, arising from sequential causes and conditions. It belongs to various causes and conditions and does not abide for a moment. It is false and unreal, arising from memory and conceptualization associated with delusion.
At that time, the Bodhisattva thinks like this:

'Ordinary beings are to be pitied. They are bound by various feelings. Because of improper contemplation of the aggregate of feelings, they give rise to attachment to pleasant feelings, attachment to painful feelings, and attachment to neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feelings. They are bound by various feelings, running and transmigrating from body to body, without rest in the five destinies.

These ordinary beings are attached to various feelings, bound by feelings, and bound by feelings. They do not escape the aggregate of feelings. They do not see the way out of the aggregate of feelings. Because they do not know how to contemplate the aggregate of feelings correctly.

They do not know how to contemplate the aggregate of feelings as impermanent in accordance with reality. They are bound by defilements of desire within the aggregate of feelings. They do not know the true characteristics of the aggregate of feelings.
We should not follow the learning of ordinary beings now. We should contemplate and select the aggregate of feelings in accordance with reality.'

Then they contemplated the aggregate of feelings in accordance with reality. The aggregate of feelings is a non-aggregate. The aggregate of feelings is an unreal aggregate. The aggregate of feelings is an inverted aggregate. The aggregate of feelings is an unstable aggregate.

At that time, seeing the true nature of the aggregate of sensation, there is no doer and no one who causes it to be done. Within the aggregate of sensation, one does not see the characteristics of the aggregate of sensation.

Thus contemplating the aggregate of sensation, one does not see the aggregate of sensation within, nor does one see the aggregate of sensation without. One does not cling to the aggregate of sensation as self, nor does one cling to the aggregate of sensation as others. One knows that the aggregate of sensation has no origin and belongs to nothing.

There is no dharma that can give rise to sensation. It is merely due to the characteristics of delusion, the fruits and retributions of karma from past lives, and the number of aggregates of sensation that one sees the aggregate of sensation as a continuation of false causes and conditions.

At that time, one does not accept, crave, or cling to the past aggregate of sensation, nor does one accept, crave, or cling to the future aggregate of sensation, nor does one accept, crave, or cling to the present aggregate of sensation.

This person eliminates the knot of craving within pleasant sensation, eliminates the knot of anger within painful sensation, and because of knowing and seeing the knot of ignorance within neither-painful-nor-pleasant sensation, diligently practices diligently.

At that time, if the bodhisattva experiences a pleasant feeling, his mind does not give rise to craving; if he experiences a painful feeling, his mind does not give rise to anger; if he experiences a feeling that is neither painful nor pleasant, his mind does not give rise to delusion.
Dhá¹›á¸hatara,
ordinary beings often give rise to craving in response to pleasant feelings, anger in response to painful feelings, and delusion in response to feelings that are neither painful nor pleasant.

Because of these feelings of craving, anger, and delusion, ordinary beings sink deeply into darkness and are unable to truly understand the aggregate of feeling. They also do not understand the characteristics of craving, anger, and delusion. They deeply cling to craving, anger, and delusion, thinking 'this is me' or 'this is mine,' or 'this is over there.'
Dhá¹›á¸hatara,
the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who correctly contemplates the aggregate of feeling in this way is not dragged around by craving, anger, or delusion.

If craving, anger, or delusion arise, he is able to eliminate them and abide in the right path. In order to sever the fetters of craving in relation to pleasant feelings, he diligently applies himself; in order to sever the fetters of anger in relation to painful feelings, he diligently applies himself; in order to sever the fetters of delusion in relation to feelings that are neither painful nor pleasant, he diligently applies himself.

If one truly understands the characteristics of the three feelings, then when there is something to be felt, whether it is suffering, happiness, or neither suffering nor happiness, one should be detached and unattached.

One should be free from the fetters of desire, anger, and ignorance. When feelings arise, one should be able to understand and see them, and understand that the aggregate of feelings is truly impermanent.

If one can understand in this way, then one will completely cut off attachment to the aggregate of feelings. One will enter the path of cutting off attachment to the aggregate of feelings, and will not be defiled by the various feelings.

If a bodhisattva contemplates the aggregate of feelings in this way, then he will truly understand the aggregate of feelings, understand the arising of the aggregate of feelings, the cessation of the aggregate of feelings, and the path to the cessation of the aggregate of feelings. He will then truly understand that the aggregate of feelings is characterized by non-arising, and will penetrate the marklessness of the aggregate of feelings with the mark of non-arising.
DhÄraá¹‡Ä«Å›vara!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should contemplate and discern the aggregate of feelings in this way.
DhÄraá¹‡Ä«Å›vara!
What is meant by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplating and discerning the aggregate of perceptions?

When the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva contemplates the aggregates correctly, he sees that the aggregate of conceptualization arises from delusion, is false, unstable, and unreal, and has never had the characteristic of arising from the beginning, arising from the power of karma in previous lives through the combination of causes and conditions.
He thinks like this:

'The aggregate is not the aggregate of conceptualization, the false aggregate is the aggregate of conceptualization, the inverted aggregate is the aggregate of conceptualization, and there is no conceptualization in the aggregate of conceptualization.

It is like a mirage in the late spring month, which is called a mirage because of its name. The aggregate of conceptualization is also like this, which is called the aggregate of conceptualization because of the characteristic of consciousness.

Ordinary people are bound by false conceptualization here, either cognizing pleasure or cognizing suffering, or cognizing neither pleasure nor suffering, or cognizing cold and heat, or cognizing male and female, or cognizing the birth and death of the five paths, or cognizing combination or cognizing dispersion, or cognizing the past or cognizing the future or cognizing the present, or cognizing good or cognizing evil, or cognizing existence or cognizing nonexistence.'
These are the thoughts of ordinary beings, all of which are inverted and false, belonging to various causes and conditions, and are merely provisionally named as the aggregate of thought.
In this, whether internal or external, there is no thinker, because ordinary beings are bound by false thoughts.

Sometimes consciousness recognizes desire, sometimes consciousness recognizes anger, sometimes consciousness recognizes ignorance, sometimes consciousness recognizes wife and children. Ordinary beings rely on this aggregate of thought and are attached to falsehood. They run and come and go in this aggregate of thought, unable to truly contemplate that the aggregate of thought is false.

Ordinary beings, with the thought of self, the thought of others, and the thought of male and female, are bound to the aggregate of thought and cannot be liberated. They are attached to the aggregate of thought, thinking 'I am the aggregate of thought' and 'This is my aggregate of thought.'
We should not follow the learning of ordinary beings.

The Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva contemplates the aggregate of thought in this way. Within the aggregate of thought, the thought of the aggregate of thought cannot be obtained, just as the characteristics of a mirage cannot be obtained within a mirage.

Bodhisattvas see the aggregate of perception as like a mirage. They do not crave, grasp, or cling to past perceptions, nor do they crave, grasp, or cling to future perceptions. They do not dwell on present perceptions, discriminating between self and others. They extinguish the path of the aggregate of perception and realize that the aggregate of perception is unborn.

They do not see the aggregate of perception coming or going, but only arising from the causes of inverted clinging to past karma and bound by present conditions. There is no aggregate of perception in the aggregate of perception. Observing and discerning the aggregate of perception, it comes from nowhere and goes nowhere. Thus, they realize the aggregate of perception is unborn. They do not discriminate the cessation of the aggregate of perception, but only in order to extinguish all the aggregate of perception and feeling, and also to abide in the knowledge and vision of the way things are.
When bodhisattvas contemplate the aggregate of perception as it really is, they distance themselves from all the paths of perception and the mind, and do not dwell in any of the paths of perception.

But they abide in the perception of knowledge and views, and also correctly perceive the aggregate of perceptions, do not crave for the aggregate of perceptions, correctly contemplate all aggregates of perceptions, and correctly know the arising, cessation, and extinction of the aggregate of perceptions.
DhÄraá¹‡Ä«Å›vara!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who thus correctly contemplate and discern the aggregate of perceptions will be free from the defilements of craving for the aggregate of perceptions, and will also be able to cultivate the path to eliminate the defilements of craving for the aggregate of perceptions.
DhÄraá¹‡Ä«Å›vara!
What is meant by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplating and discerning the aggregate of formations?
DhÄraá¹‡Ä«Å›vara!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the aggregate of formations arising from delusion, falsely remembering and discriminating as if borrowed into existence.
When bodhisattvas are engaged in bodily, verbal, or mental actions at that time, they all contemplate them as impure, impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self.
When contemplating in this way, they think like this:

'The aggregate of formations is not the aggregate of formations, the aggregate of suffering is the aggregate of formations, the aggregate of formations arising from causes and conditions is the aggregate of formations, the aggregate of formations is the aggregate of formations, and all aggregates of formations are neither increasing nor decreasing, nor accumulating.
If bodily actions, verbal actions, and mental actions have no doer, the wise do not grasp or accept this aggregate of actions.
Why is it so?
These bodily actions are not within the body, not outside the body, and not in between.
Verbal actions and mental actions are also like this, not within the mind, not outside the mind, and not in between.
Within the aggregate of actions, there is no characteristic of the aggregate of actions.
Why is it so?

This aggregate of actions arises from various causes and conditions, is false and unreal, is included in the fruits of past karma, and is also bound by causes and conditions, and is able to perform actions.

All actions, whether bodily actions, verbal actions, or mental actions, are not true actions, are actions of non-existence, are false actions, are inverted actions, and therefore it is said that the non-aggregate is the aggregate of actions.
Why is it so?

The wise do not ascertain the characteristics of the aggregate of formations, thinking 'this is bodily action, this is verbal action, this is mental action,' whether internally, externally, or in between.

Moreover, bodily, verbal, and mental actions are still without any ascertainable characteristics of action that can be obtained or spoken of, let alone the aggregate of formations that can be obtained or spoken of.
Therefore, it is said that the absence of aggregates is the aggregate of formations.

Ordinary beings give rise to inverted thoughts and are attached to bodily, verbal, and mental actions. They recollect and discriminate this as the aggregate of formations, and are bound by the aggregate of formations, running and coming and going.

Because these ordinary beings are inverted, they give rise to bodily, verbal, and mental actions. Having given rise to them, they are attached and return to them. They give rise to the notion of dharmas where there are no dharmas, and the notion of aggregates where there are no aggregates.

Because they are attached to inverted actions, they are bound by the aggregate of formations and come and go in the five destinies. They always follow bodily, verbal, and mental actions, and are unable to truly observe bodily, verbal, and mental actions. Having given rise to pleasant actions, they attain a pleasant body; having given rise to painful actions, they attain a painful body; having given rise to neither painful nor pleasant actions, they attain a body that is neither painful nor pleasant.
